- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the app for the first time
2. Click the big blue Open Folder button
3. Select any folder to open
4. Finder window closes and nothing happens

Expected Behavior:
When clicking open on the folder that I wanted the folder should have imported

Closing and reopening the app fixed the issue

data.title: Latin1 encoded files are not auto-detected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
I need to "Reopen file with Encoding" for a Latin-1 file every time i open that file to show accented chars correctly, i tried to save the file with the new encoding but does not work.

i wish Vscode can auto-detect the encoding or at least remember the encoding of the file when i open it.

Thank you guys, keep up the awesome work.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
Version 1.14.2
Commit cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e
Date 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0


- OS Version:
Xubuntu 16.04 xenial 
4.10.0-30-generic #34~16.04.1-Ubuntu 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a Latin-1 file in editor (displays in UTF-8 by default)
2. Change encoding to Western (ISO-8859-1)
3. Save and close the file
4. Open same file again and it's displayed as UTF-8

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

data.title: VSCode 1.15 is not rendering the terminals for cmd.exe and bash.exe
data.body:
I'm using the VSCode x32 to call for this report, but the problem happened on x64 distribution.
After i install it, it won't show the terminals for cmd.exe and bash.exe. The terminal opens and dot not show anything on its window.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
bower|don|0.0.3
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0
hg|mrc|1.1.5
csharp|ms-|1.12.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Version 1.15.1 on Windows 10 Professional x64, build 15063.
2. Select any terminal on user configurations.
3. Open the terminal.

My settings.json:
```
{
// Editor
    "editor.fontSize": 18,
    "editor.renderWhitespace": "boundary",
    "editor.minimap.enabled": true,
// Files
    "files.exclude": {
        "**/bin": true,
        "**/obj": true,
        "**/*.orig": true,       // backup files from version control
        "**/.idea": true,       // pycharm file
        "**/sessions.db": true, // linesman database
        "**/.sonarlint": true,
        "**/.sonar": true,
        "**/.vscode": true,
        "**/*.pyc": true,       // compiled python
        "**/.git": true,
        "**/.svn": true,
        "**/.hg": true,
        "**/.DS_Store": true    // OSX storage file
    },
    "files.autoSave": "onFocusChange",
    
    // Integrated Terminal
    "terminal.integrated.lineHeight": 1,
    "terminal.integrated.fontSize": 18,

    "workbench.colorTheme": "Monokai Dimmed",
    "window.zoomLevel": 0
}
```

data.title: How to use vscode namespace api in a Debug Adapter?

<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Win10 RS2

How can I use vscode namespace api in an implementation of DebugSession (or say Debug Adapter)?

For example, I want to use https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#extensions.getExtension in my implementation of DebugSession. But this API is not available in the runtime of the DebugSession 

What is the recommended way to work around it?

data.title: Emmet Question: How to create user snippet or extension for common tasks?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (aebaece67321b35f133be393fe8adcd50333d5ee, 2017-08-18T05:10:40.239Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ng-template|Ang|0.1.4
code-settings-sync|Sha|2.8.2
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
html-snippets|abu|0.1.0
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.19.0
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
Angular2|joh|2.4.0
ecdc|mit|0.10.3
HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3
vscode-autoprefixer|mrm|2.1.2
vscode-stylefmt|mrm|2.5.0
angular2-inline|nat|0.0.17
stylelint|shi|0.28.0
ayu|tea|0.5.0
change-case|wma|1.0.0

(4 theme extensions excluded)


---

@ramya-rao-a  A question, not a bug:

1. I find myself using `Emmet > Wrap Lines with Abbreviation` and then `ul>li*|t` a lot to create unordered lists from text pasted from text editors and word processors.
2. I have mapped a shortcut to invoke the `Emmet > Wrap Lines with Abbreviation`  command, but then have to type the mnemonic.
3. The is by design and fine, but I'd like to create a complete shortcut for this entire class.  I can't figure out how to construct a snippet or command to wrap the selected lines with `ul>li*|t`.

Can someone please point me in the right direction?  If needed, I'll create an extension for this.

data.title: Type aliases not respected when auto-implementing a TypeScript interface
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an interface such as:

```export type integer = number;
export interface IFoo {
    bar(baz: integer): Promise<integer>;
}
```

2. Go to a different file and write:

```
    import { integer, IFoo } from './location';
    export class Foo implements IFoo { }
```

3. Position the cursor over the `Foo` identifier to obtain the error and light bulb.  Click the light bulb and click `Implement interface 'IFoo'`.

Observed: The class is populated like so:

    export class Foo implements IFoo {
        bar(baz: number): Promise<number> {
            throw new Error('Not yet implemented');
        }
    }

Expected: Type aliases are honored:

    export class Foo implements IFoo {
        bar(baz: integer): Promise<integer> {
            throw new Error('Not yet implemented');
        }
    }

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Moving the cursor should not cancel tab stops in a snippet
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- solargraph|cas|0.7.0 cpptools|ms-|0.12.3 Ruby|reb|0.14.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a .html file. 2. Type `a` and press `tab`. The cursor should now be between the double quotes after `href`. 3. Move the cursor. 4. Press `tab` again. 5. Verify that rather than jumping to the next tab stop, pressing `tab` has inserted a tab whitespace character. The same issue occurs using the following user-defined snippet rather than the emmet abbreviation: "link": { "prefix": "a", "body": "$2" }, I'm assuming that this is not intended behavior, but if it is, I feel like there should be a setting to disable it. Moving the cursor to copy-paste text into snippet tab stops is an important part of some of my workflows, and I don't think I'm alone in that (this used to work in previous versions; I am not 100% sure in which version this issue first emerged). Reproduces without extensions: Yes

- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In editor pane, type **Test-Pa** and press tab to tab complete (should work).
2. Delete any character(s) in 'Path' and press tab again and see that a tab character is inserted instead of completing the syntax.

Any cmdlet, parameter or value will not be tab completed.

This issue doesn't appear when using the Terminal pane.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: N/A

data.title: resolveDocumentLink shouldn't use 'new' links
data.body:
Like `CompletionItems`, `DocumentLinks` that are to be resolved should be kept and the `resolve` function should receive the original instance. That will allow extensions to keep state in there. 

Branched from: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9940#issuecomment-323369876

data.title: PATH environment variable name is case sensitive in the settings on windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
overtype|ada|0.2.0
swagger-viewer|Arj|1.4.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0
crane|Hvy|0.3.8
asciidoctor-vscode|joa|0.3.5
language-asciidoc|jus|1.3.1
vscode-rust|kal|0.4.2
php-symbols|lin|2.1.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8



---

It appears that "terminal.integrated.env.windows" is weirdly case sensitive on Windows.


```
  "terminal.integrated.env.windows": {
    "Path" : "blah"
  }
```

in the powershell:

$Env:Path 
blah
$Env:PATH
blah


If you make it
```
{
  "terminal.integrated.env.windows": {
    "PATH" : "blah"
  }
}
```
Then it'll fail to override path altogether....

$Env:Path
BLOB OF SYSTEM PATHS
$Env:PATH
BLOB OF SYSTEM PATHS


If you make it

```
{
  "terminal.integrated.env.windows": {
    "PATH2" : "blah"
  }
}
```

$Env:PATH2
Blah
$Env:Path2
Blah

data.title: Show hover commmand causes error

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.15.1
- OS Version:Win x64

Executing the 'show hover' command/shortcut causes pop-up error ```Cannot read property 'startShowingAt' of undefined```

I have disabled hover as it is too noisy for my taste.  That said, it would be nice if there were a way to activate it manually.  I was specifically trying to show the new color picker, but being able to show keyword hovers on request would be great as well.

Reproduce
1. Disable hover in settings (```"editor.hover":false```)
2. Relaunch vscode
3. Move cursor to desired keyword and execute "show hover" command

data.title: Suggestion: Add Release Notes to Settings Gear
data.body:
A small request...
In the June version of VSCode, the update info menu was replaced with the gear in the bottom left corner.  However, with that gear, it no longer gives the opportunity to check the release notes before updating.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10420943/29462590-80d9b5f6-83f5-11e7-973a-12b45f334dfe.png)

data.title: Feature Request: Add fool proof GIT support.
data.body: There are lots of ways to shoot yourself in the foot with GIT.  Can you please add complete, native support for GIT like they have in IDEA-J?

data.title: Keep the name of property not being translated.
[php] Incorrect Syntax Hghlighting in comment
data.body:
Using a custom user snippet causes the green coloring of the comment to continue on past the end of comment. The issue seems to happen when the comment start with a double star /\*\* ... \*/ but goes away if /\*\*\* .. \*/ or /\* ... \*/. I've been using this snippet since I started using Code the issue seems have appeared in one the latest releases around 1.14.* 

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
githistory|don|0.2.3
phpunit|ema|1.0.0
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.5.0
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.6

(5 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a PHP user snippet:
```JSON
        "Function Comments" : {
		"prefix": "doxy_func_comment",
		"body": [
			"/**",
			" * @brief $1",
			" * ",
			" * @param ($2) $3 - $4",
			" * @return $5, otherwise false",
			" *",
			" * @details $6",
			" */"
		],
		"description": "Doxygen Commenting with full description"
	}
```
2. Use the snippet
3. The green commenting color should stop at the end of the snippet. 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: C# code formatting ignoring EditorConfig settings
data.body:
Format selection / Format document commands seem to ignore the current EditorConfig settings when applied to a C# file.

I'm not sure if this repo is the right place for to log the issue. Please correct me if it should be elsewhere.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
path-intellisense|chr|1.4.2
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
vscode-svgviewer|css|1.4.2
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
githistory|don|0.2.3
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
vscode-flatland-icon-theme|geb|0.0.6
vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4
icon-fonts|idl|1.8.0
vscode-angular2-emmet|jak|2.0.3
Angular2|joh|2.4.0
vscode-less|mrm|0.6.3
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-|0.0.23
vs-keybindings|ms-|0.1.7
sass-indented|rob|1.4.1
autoimport|ste|1.2.2

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have the following `.editorconfig` file in a directory:
```
root = true

[*]
indent_style = tab
````
2. Create a new C# file indented with tabs
3. Run Format Document command on it
4. See that tabs were converted to spaces.

One thing to note - `"omnisharp.useEditorFormattingSettings"` is set to `true` in my configuration.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: 'Join Lines' triggers unexpected pasting of text
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
spellright|ban|1.1.14
python|don|0.7.0
cpptools|ms-|0.12.3
csharp|ms-|1.12.1
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
blank-line-organizer|rin|0.1.2
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
change-case|wma|1.0.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start VS Code with no files open.
2. Ctrl + N to start a new plain text document.
3. Type some words on two lines.
4. Select all.
5. Issue the command 'Join Lines'.
6. With the text still selected, click on some other application window to give focus to that other application.
7. Click back in the whitespace of the editor of VS Code.
8. Notice that the selected text gets pasted for some reason, at the end of what was previously selected.
9. Thereafter (i.e. once this bug has been triggered), if you simply select text, click on some other window, and then click back in VS Code, that text will get pasted. Most times.

Starting with all extensions disabled makes no difference.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Minor highlighting bug in JS/TS template strings
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 x64

Dot notations and similar special characters used in code (brackets, commas) inside template strings are highlighted with the string highlighting color instead of proper highlighting color.

Code *inside* template strings:
![selection_034](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16593597/29455354-2a18ffbc-8411-11e7-8907-72831711f1ee.png)
![selection_035](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16593597/29455357-2bdc7176-8411-11e7-9344-a584e3f4ca6f.png)

Code *outside* template strings:
![selection_036](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16593597/29455416-5a233164-8411-11e7-98c1-45e4d000d6ae.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Position in file is lost when tabbing back and forth and find window is open
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.51.1 64bit
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

You need the C# extension for this:

1. Open two actual C# files in Visual Studio Code.
2. Press Control + F to find something in one of the open files. Please note at roughly which line you are looking at.
3. Click the other tab or Ctrl+tab to switch.
4. Now click or ctrl+tab to switch back to the first file.
5. You will now be several lines below in the file than what you were previously.

If it doesn't happen the first time, repeat the tabbing back and forth a couple of times while keeping the find dialogue open.

I would expect I would be in the same place I left it.

This is related to the C# extension (and possibly similar extensions). I think it's because of the extra lines it adds (like the references). Not sure why it only happens when you have the find dialogue open.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: No intellisense for node_module's JSDoc types referenced in another file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:06:21.685Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
vscode-nsp|ada|1.0.1
vscode-standardjs|che|1.1.7
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
vscode-babel-coloring|dza|0.0.4
gitlens|eam|4.3.3
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.5.0
vscode-firefox-debug|hbe|0.15.3
vscode-auto-open-markdown-preview|hnw|0.0.4
rest-client|hum|0.15.1
jenkins-declarative-support|jmM|0.1.0
VS-code-vagrantfile|mar|0.0.5
terraform|mau|0.0.16
vscode-duplicate|mrm|1.2.0
vscode-scss|mrm|0.6.2
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.8
Ruby|reb|0.14.0
java|red|0.8.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0
jenkinsfile-support|sec|0.1.0
ayu|tea|0.5.0
pdf|tom|0.2.0
vscode-todo-highlight|way|0.5.8
jinja|who|0.0.8
save-and-run|wk-|0.0.14

This may be due to circular type references. In my repro I have type A returning an instance of type B, which returns the original type A later. When this final return happens, all typing information is lost.

As a simple example:

```javascript

// File A

class A {
  something () {
    return new B(this)
  }
}

// File B

class B {
  constructor (a) {
    this.a = a
  }

  somethingElse () {
    return this.a
  }
}

// Consumer file

const a = new A().something().somethingElse() // determined to be 'any' instead of 'A'
```

Please see attached repro for a working example demonstrating this behaviour.

[repro.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1234091/repro.zip)
